nodes.text: The rights of clinical trial subjects should be protected
The safety of clinical trial subjects should be protected
The dignity of clinical trial subjects should be protected
The well-being of clinical trial subjects should be protected
Data generated in clinical trials should be reliable and robust
The interests of subjects should take priority over all other interests
Define 'clinical study' as a broader concept that includes clinical trials
Define 'clinical trial' as a category of clinical study based on specific criteria
Align definitions with international guidelines and EU law on medicinal products
Simplify and harmonize administrative provisions for clinical trials in the EU
Enable conducting a single clinical trial across multiple EU Member States
Consider scientific developments suggesting future trials will target specific populations
Use Case Report Forms (CRFs) to collect clinical trial data
Ensure compliance with all applicable regulations for clinical trials
Clinical trials should include subgroups identified through genomic information
Clinical trials may involve many or all Member States to include sufficient patients
Application dossiers must be submitted through a single submission portal
Single Member State trial applications should also use the single submission portal
Sponsors and investigators may rely directly on the Regulation's provisions
Safety reporting must follow the Regulation's provisions
Labeling of investigational medicinal products must follow the Regulation's provisions
Establish an Independent Data-Monitoring Committee (IDMC)
Member States should cooperate in assessing clinical trial authorization requests
The clinical trial authorization procedure should be flexible and efficient
The authorization procedure must not compromise patient safety or public health
Timelines for assessing clinical trial applications should be sufficient to assess the file
The concept of tacit authorization should be maintained to ensure timelines are adhered to
Member States may assess and authorize clinical trial applications swiftly in a public health crisis
A legally acceptable representative may provide consent for participants unable to do so
Clinical trials for ultra-rare diseases should be fostered
Member States must assess all clinical trials applications within given timelines
Rapid assessment is important for trials on severe conditions with limited treatment options
Risk to subject safety stems from investigational product and intervention
Low-intervention trials are important for assessing standard treatments
Original medical records must be maintained
A protocol must be established for clinical trials
Protocol amendments should be documented
Clinical trials with less stringent rules should be subject to less strict monitoring requirements
Clinical trials with less stringent rules should have reduced requirements for master file contents
Clinical trials with less stringent rules should have reduced traceability requirements for investigational medicinal products
Clinical trials with less stringent rules must follow the same application procedure as other clinical trials
Published scientific evidence supporting safety and efficacy may include high quality data from scientific journal articles
Published scientific evidence may include national, regional or institutional treatment protocols
Published scientific evidence may include health technology assessment reports
Define standard operating procedures (SOPs)
Clinical trial applications should be assessed for anticipated therapeutic and public health benefits
Clinical trial applications should be assessed for risk and inconvenience to subjects
Use of surrogate endpoints in clinical trials must be justified
Trial subjects should represent population groups likely to use the investigational product
Medicinal products likely to have significant clinical value should be studied in vulnerable groups
Effects of medicinal products should be studied in frail or older people
Protect health and well-being of subjects belonging to specific groups
Allow extension of assessment timelines for sponsors to address questions
Ensure sufficient time to assess additional information within extension period
Address all aspects of subject protection in trial authorization
Address data reliability and robustness in trial authorization
Issue single administrative decision for trial authorization
Involve ethics committees in trial authorization process
Include laypersons, patients, or patient organizations in assessment bodies
Ensure necessary expertise is available for assessing clinical trial applications
Assessment should be done jointly by persons with necessary qualifications and experience
Persons assessing applications must be independent of the sponsor, trial site, and investigators
Consider specific expertise for trials involving emergency situations, minors, or incapacitated subjects
Allow sponsors to submit applications based on documents jointly assessed by relevant Member States
Allow sponsors to withdraw applications for clinical trial authorization
Participants must be informed who will have access to their personal data
Application withdrawal should only be for the entire clinical trial
Sponsors may submit a new application after withdrawing a previous one
An authorization mechanism should allow extending trials to additional Member States
Trial extension should avoid re-assessment by all initially involved Member States
Substantial modifications impacting safety or data reliability require re-authorization
Adapt consent guidance to local requirements for pediatric clinical trials
Noncompliance in clinical trials must be addressed
Clinical trial reports must be prepared
Application dossier content for clinical trial authorization should be harmonized across Member States
Clinical trial data must be recorded in a publicly accessible and free database
Clinical trial database should be a primary or partner registry of WHO ICTRP
Member States should establish language requirements for the application dossier
Member States should consider accepting a common medical language for non-subject documentation
Human dignity and right to integrity of the person must be recognized
Include methods for assessing efficacy in the protocol
Describe safety assessment procedures in the protocol
Any intervention in biology and medicine requires free and informed consent of the person concerned
Rules for protection of subjects in Directive 2001/20/EC should be upheld
Member States should determine legally designated representatives for incapacitated persons and minors
Specific protection measures are required for incapacitated subjects, minors, pregnant and breastfeeding women
A qualified medical doctor or dental practitioner should be responsible for all medical care provided to subjects
Universities and research institutions may collect clinical trial data for future scientific research
Subject must give consent to use their data outside the clinical trial protocol
Subjects have the right to withdraw consent for data use at any time
Research projects using trial data should be reviewed for ethical aspects
Informed consent should be obtained in writing
Alternative consent recording methods may be used if subject cannot write
Subjects should receive information in understandable language before consent
Investigators should consider circumstances influencing a subject's decision to participate
Investigators should assess if subjects are from disadvantaged groups
Investigators should evaluate if subjects are in situations of dependency
Minors capable of forming an opinion should assent to participate
Simplified informed consent may be used for certain group-allocation trials
Investigational products in simplified consent trials must be used per marketing authorizations
Non-participation in a clinical trial should only result in data not being used for that trial
Clinical trials comparing established treatments should be conducted within a single Member State
Define specific provisions to protect pregnant and breastfeeding women in clinical trials
Provide additional protective measures for persons in situations of dependency or vulnerability
Member States may maintain additional protective measures for vulnerable participants
Provide clear rules for informed consent in emergency situations
Documentation must allow reconstruction of the course of events
Blinding procedures should be used to keep parties unaware of treatment assignments
Patients may be enrolled in emergency clinical trials without prior informed consent under strict conditions
Emergency clinical trials must relate directly to the patient's medical condition preventing informed consent
Any previously expressed objection by the patient must be respected
Informed consent should be sought as soon as possible after emergency enrollment
The start of a clinical trial must be notified to the Member State
The end of subject recruitment for a clinical trial must be notified to the Member State
The end of a clinical trial must be notified to the Member State
Clinical trial results should be reported within one year from the end of the trial
The sponsor should submit a summary of the clinical trial results
The sponsor should submit a layperson-understandable summary of the results
The sponsor should submit the clinical study report, where applicable
Sponsors must justify in the protocol if results cannot be submitted within defined timelines
Investigators should report all serious adverse events to the sponsor
Sponsors must assess safety information received from investigators
Report suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions to the European Medicines Agency
The Agency should forward adverse event information to Member States for assessment
Follow ICH guidelines on good clinical practice when designing, conducting, and reporting trials
Ensure clinical trials are consistent with World Medical Association's Declaration of Helsinki
Sponsors should adequately monitor the conduct of clinical trials
Monitoring should ensure reliability and robustness of trial results
Consider clinical trial characteristics when establishing monitoring extent
Investigators and healthcare professionals must be qualified to perform their tasks
Facilities where clinical trials are conducted should be suitable
Ensure traceability of investigational medicinal products
Have arrangements for storage of investigational medicinal products
Sponsors must report serious breaches of trial conduct rules to Member States
Report events relevant to benefit-risk balance to Member States in a timely manner
Notify Member States of unexpected events that may influence benefit-risk assessment
Report unexpected events that would lead to changes in medicinal product administration
Report unexpected events that would lead to changes in overall trial conduct
Sponsors may take urgent safety measures without prior authorization
Apply for substantial modification before restarting a temporarily halted trial
Sponsor should supply investigators with an investigator's brochure
Register trial in EudraCT before starting
Clinical trial information should be recorded adequately
Clinical trial information should be handled adequately
Clinical trial information should be stored adequately
A clinical trial master file must be kept by the sponsor
A clinical trial master file must be kept by the investigator
The clinical trial master file should be archived appropriately after the trial ends
Establish specific rules for investigational medicinal products in clinical trials
Distinguish between investigational and auxiliary medicinal products
Establish rules for manufacturing and import of investigational medicinal products
Establish rules for manufacturing and import of auxiliary medicinal products
Rules should reflect existing good manufacturing practices for medicinal products
Allow deviations from rules in specific cases to facilitate clinical trial conduct
Describe procedures, tests, and measurements according to the trial protocol
Rules should allow flexibility in clinical trials if subject safety and data quality are not compromised
Authorization for manufacture/import of investigational medicinal products is not required for certain radiopharmaceuticals
Investigational and auxiliary medicinal products must be appropriately labelled
Labeling rules should be adapted to risks to subject safety and data reliability
Additional labeling is not required for authorized medicinal products in certain clinical trials
Use flow-charts to explain trial visits and schedule
Source data must include all information necessary to reconstruct and evaluate the trial
Source documents must be original records or certified copies
Specific labeling rules apply for radiopharmaceuticals used as diagnostic investigational medicinal products
Clinical trials must have a designated 'sponsor'
Research networks should be allowed to co-sponsor a clinical trial
All co-sponsors of a clinical trial are subject to the full responsibilities of sponsorship
Sponsors must follow Community procedures for authorization and supervision of medicinal products
Explain the scientific rationale for genetic testing if planned in a trial
Subinvestigators must be designated and supervised by the investigator
Co-sponsors should split up sponsor responsibilities by contractual agreement
Sponsors not established in the EU must have a legal representative in the EU
Sponsors must establish at least a contact person in the EU
Liability for damages caused during clinical trials is governed by national law
Member States should ensure compensation systems for damages to subjects are in place
Compensation systems should be appropriate to the nature and extent of risk
Member States should have the power to revoke authorization of a clinical trial
Member States should have the power to suspend a clinical trial
Member States should have the power to require sponsors to modify a clinical trial
Member States should be able to conduct inspections of clinical trials
Member States must have adequate inspection capacities for clinical trials
The Commission should be able to control if Member States supervise compliance with this Regulation
Clinical trials should be linked together by EU trial number with hyperlinks
All clinical trials must be registered in the EU database before starting
Start and end dates of subject recruitment should be published in the EU database
No personal data of trial participants should be recorded in the EU database
Information in the EU database should be public unless specific reasons require otherwise
Clinical study report data should not be considered commercially confidential after marketing authorization
Explain options for further care/medication after trial discontinuation
Implement quality assurance procedures for every aspect of the trial
Main characteristics of a clinical trial should not be considered confidential
Conclusion on Part I of clinical trial authorization assessment report should not be confidential
Decision on clinical trial authorization should not be considered confidential
Clinical trial results should not be considered confidential
Each Member State should designate one contact point for clinical trial authorization
Member States should not require multiple payments to different bodies for clinical trial assessment
Small tokens of appreciation must be approved by the Ethics Committee
The Commission shall establish rules on cooperation between Member States for assessing sponsor-provided Eudravigilance data
The Commission shall specify detailed arrangements for inspection procedures
The Commission may amend Annexes I, II, IV and V to adapt to technical progress
The Commission may amend Annexes to account for international regulatory developments in clinical trials
The Commission may amend Annex III to improve information on medicinal product safety
The Commission shall specify principles of good manufacturing practice for clinical trials
The Commission should carry out appropriate consultations during preparatory work
The Commission must ensure timely transmission of documents to European Parliament and Council
National laws prohibiting abortifacients are not affected by this Regulation
National laws restricting use of human/animal cells are not affected by this Regulation
National laws prohibiting medicinal products with narcotics are not affected by this Regulation
Information about who has reviewed/approved the trial must be provided
Information about the sponsor/funding of the trial must be provided
It should be stated that the hospital receives money, not the investigator directly
Member States should communicate national provisions on narcotic drugs to the Commission
Gene therapy trials that modify germ line genetic identity are prohibited
Directive 95/46/EC applies to personal data processing in Member States under this Regulation
Member State competent authorities must supervise personal data processing
Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies to personal data processing by the Commission and Agency
Resolve any unclear issues during the consent/assent discussion
Consider using an additional summary leaflet for complex trials
No subject should be admitted to a trial before IRB/IEC written approval
Personal data protection rights must encompass the right to access, rectification and withdrawal
Situations when restrictions on data protection rights may be imposed must be specified
Withdrawal of informed consent should not affect results of activities already carried out
Subjects should not have to pay for investigational medicinal products
Subjects should not have to pay for procedures specifically required by the trial protocol
The authorization procedure should apply as soon as possible
Extensive IT functionalities are required for the authorization procedure
Investigators should provide evidence of qualifications through up-to-date CV and other relevant documentation
The EU portal and EU database must be verified as fully functional before regulations apply
Directive 2001/20/EC should be repealed
Sponsors should be allowed to conduct trials under Directive 2001/20/EC during a transition period
The Regulation must align with international guidance documents on clinical trials
Member States should take measures to encourage clinical trials by non-commercial sponsors
Measures to encourage non-commercial sponsors must not compromise trial quality
Investigator should have sufficient time to properly conduct and complete the trial within agreed period
Investigator should have adequate qualified staff and facilities for trial duration to conduct trial properly and safely
Clinical trials must ensure a high level of protection of health
Medicinal products must meet high standards of quality and safety
Rules for conducting clinical trials shall be harmonized across the EU
Clinical trial data must be acceptable throughout the EU
Medicinal products used in clinical trials shall move freely within the EU
Clinical trial data must be reliable and robust
Ensure quality and safety standards for medicinal products used in clinical trials
Ensure safety of subjects participating in clinical trials
Protect personal data of individuals involved in clinical trials
Respect fundamental rights recognized in the Charter when applying this Regulation
Apply the Regulation in accordance with human dignity and integrity of the person
Ensure clinical trial data are reliable throughout the Union
Protocol deviations allowed to eliminate immediate hazards to subjects
Clinical trials must respect the rights, safety, dignity and well-being of subjects
This Regulation applies to all clinical trials conducted in the Union
This Regulation does not apply to non-interventional studies
Definitions from Article 1 of Directive 2001/83/EC apply to this Regulation
Clinical studies must investigate effects of medicinal products in humans
Clinical studies must identify adverse reactions to medicinal products
Investigator may assign product accountability duties to an appropriate pharmacist or individual
Records of product delivery, inventory, use, and return must be maintained
Study the absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of medicinal products
Ascertain the safety and efficacy of medicinal products in clinical studies
Decide subject assignment to therapeutic strategy in advance
Make decision to prescribe investigational medicinal products with subject inclusion
Apply additional diagnostic or monitoring procedures beyond normal clinical practice
Use authorized investigational medicinal products in low-intervention trials
Use investigational medicinal products according to marketing authorization terms
Investigator should follow the trial's randomization procedures
Additional diagnostic or monitoring procedures must not pose more than minimal risk to subjects
Additional procedures must not pose more than minimal burden compared to normal clinical practice
Non-interventional studies are defined as clinical studies other than clinical trials
Investigational medicinal products include those being tested or used as reference/placebo
Normal clinical practice means typical treatment to treat, prevent, or diagnose a condition
Advanced therapy investigational products must meet the definition in Regulation (EC) No 1394/2007
Auxiliary medicinal products are used for trial needs as described in the protocol
Authorised auxiliary medicinal products must be approved under Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 or Directive 2001/83/EC
Ethics committees must be established in Member States in accordance with national law
Ethics committees must include laypersons, particularly patients or patient organizations
Substantial modifications are changes likely to impact subject safety/rights or data reliability/robustness
Sponsors are responsible for initiating, managing and financing clinical trials
Written informed consent form must be signed prior to subject's trial participation
An investigator is responsible for conducting a clinical trial at a site
A principal investigator leads a team of investigators at a trial site
A subject participates in a clinical trial as recipient of investigational product or control
A minor is defined as under the age of legal competence to give informed consent
An incapacitated subject is incapable of giving informed consent for non-age reasons
A legally designated representative can give informed consent for incapacitated subjects or minors
Obtain informed consent from subjects before participation in clinical trials
Get authorization from legally designated representatives for minors and incapacitated subjects
Describe objectives, design, methodology, and organization in the clinical trial protocol
Include clinical and non-clinical data on investigational products in the Investigator's Brochure
Define the start of a clinical trial in the protocol if different from first subject recruitment
Define the end of a clinical trial in the protocol if later than last subject visit
Specify conditions for early termination of a clinical trial in the protocol
Sponsors must intend to resume a temporarily halted clinical trial
Member States may suspend the conduct of a clinical trial
Clinical trials must follow good clinical practice requirements
Clinical trials must protect the rights, safety and well-being of subjects
Data generated in clinical trials must be reliable and robust
Competent authorities may inspect clinical trial sites and related facilities
Adverse events must be recorded for subjects administered medicinal products
Provide subjects with a copy of signed informed consent form
Serious adverse events requiring hospitalization must be reported
Unexpected serious adverse reactions inconsistent with safety info must be reported
Clinical study reports must be prepared according to Annex I, Part I, Module 5 of Directive 2001/83/EC
Incapacitated minors shall be classified as incapacitated subjects
Clinical trials must protect subjects' rights, safety, dignity and well-being above all else
Clinical trials must be designed to generate reliable and robust data
An ethics committee must perform an ethical review of clinical trials
The ethical review must be conducted according to Member State law
Member States shall ensure ethics committee timelines are compatible with this Regulation
Sponsors must submit clinical trial applications through the EU portal
The sponsor shall propose one Member State as reporting Member State
Member States must notify changes to reporting Member State within 3 days
Investigators must ensure accuracy and completeness of data reported to sponsor
CRF data must be consistent with source documents
If only one Member State is willing or involved, that State shall be the reporting Member State
If no State is willing, the reporting State shall be selected by agreement among concerned States
The reporting Member State shall notify the sponsor and other States within 6 days of application
For low-intervention trials, sponsor shall propose an evidence-based State as reporting State
The reporting Member State shall validate the application within 10 days of submission
Investigators must maintain trial documents as specified in Essential Documents
Investigators should prevent accidental or premature destruction of trial documents
Essential documents should be retained for at least 2 years after last marketing approval
The reporting Member State must notify the sponsor if the trial falls within the Regulation's scope
The reporting Member State must notify the sponsor if the application dossier is complete
Member States may communicate considerations on application validation within 7 days
If not notified otherwise, the trial is deemed to fall within scope after the notification period
The reporting Member State must inform sponsors of incomplete applications via the EU portal
Sponsors have up to 10 days to comment on or complete applications via the EU portal
The reporting Member State must review comments/completions within 5 days of receipt
Identify subjects by unique code numbers in adverse event reports
The reporting Member State must notify the sponsor if the application complies with requirements
The sponsor must provide comments or complete the application dossier within the specified period
The date of sponsor notification shall be the validation date of the application
The reporting Member State shall assess if the trial is a low-intervention clinical trial
The reporting Member State shall assess compliance with Chapter V
The assessment shall consider anticipated therapeutic and public health benefits
Investigator must inform institution if terminating trial without sponsor agreement
Provide sponsor and IRB/IEC detailed written explanation for trial termination
Consider characteristics of and knowledge about investigational medicinal products
Assess relevance of clinical trial, including subject group representation
Evaluate current state of scientific knowledge related to the trial
Consider regulatory authority recommendations or requirements for the trial
Assess reliability and robustness of trial data, including statistical approaches
Evaluate risks and inconveniences for trial subjects
Compare characteristics of trial intervention to normal clinical practice
Investigator/institution should provide IRB/IEC with trial outcome summary upon completion
Safety measures must include risk minimisation measures
Safety measures must include monitoring procedures
Safety measures must include safety reporting processes
Comply with requirements for manufacturing investigational medicinal products
Comply with labelling requirements set out in Chapter X
Ensure completeness and adequacy of the investigator's brochure
Reporting Member State must draw up an assessment report
The reporting Member State must submit assessment conclusions within 45 days of validation date
Multi-state clinical trials shall have a 3-phase assessment process
Initial assessment phase by reporting Member State must be completed within 26 days
Coordinated review phase involving all Member States must be completed within 12 days
Consolidation phase by reporting Member State must be completed within 7 days
Reporting Member State shall develop draft Part I of assessment report during initial phase
All Member States shall jointly review application during coordinated review phase
Sponsor should ensure electronic data processing systems conform to requirements
Reporting Member State shall consider other Member States' input when finalizing Part I of assessment report
Reporting Member State shall record how all considerations were addressed in Part I of assessment report
Reporting Member State shall submit final Part I of assessment report to sponsor and other Member States
Date of final Part I submission to sponsor and other Member States shall be the reporting date
Reporting Member State may extend assessment period by 50 days for advanced therapy trials
Only reporting Member State may request additional information from sponsor between validation and reporting dates
Use an unambiguous subject identification code for each subject
Retain all sponsor-specific essential documents pertaining to the trial
The reporting Member State may extend the period by a maximum of 31 days
The sponsor shall submit requested additional information within the period set by the reporting Member State
The period for submitting additional information shall not exceed 12 days from receipt of the request
Member States shall jointly review additional information with the original application
The coordinated review shall be performed within 12 days of receiving additional information
Further consolidation shall be performed within 7 days of the end of coordinated review
The reporting Member State shall record how all considerations have been dealt with
Member States shall assess compliance with informed consent requirements
Member States shall assess compliance with subject compensation requirements
Member States shall assess compliance with subject recruitment requirements
Member States shall assess compliance with Directive 95/46/EC
Member States shall complete assessment within 45 days of validation date
Member States shall submit Part II of assessment report via EU portal
Member States may request additional information from sponsor within assessment period
Investigator must retain essential trial documents until notified by sponsor
Member State may extend review period by up to 31 days to obtain additional information
Sponsor must submit requested additional information within 12 days of receiving request
Member State shall complete assessment within 19 days of receiving additional information
Application lapses if sponsor does not provide additional information within set period
Additional information requests and submissions must be made through the EU portal
Member State shall notify sponsor of clinical trial authorization decision via EU portal
Authorization decision must be communicated within 5 days of reporting or assessment end date
Sponsor should submit required applications to authorities before initiating clinical trials
Authorization subject to conditions must be restricted to conditions that cannot be fulfilled at the time of authorization
The reporting Member State's conclusion on Part I shall be deemed the conclusion of all Member States concerned
Member States may disagree with the reporting Member State's conclusion only on specific grounds
Member States may disagree if participation would lead to inferior treatment compared to normal clinical practice
Member States may disagree if there is infringement of national law as referred to in Article 90
Member States may disagree based on subject safety and data reliability considerations
Disagreeing Member States must communicate disagreement with justification through the EU portal
Member State must include conclusion on Part II in decision if Part I is acceptable
Member State shall refuse authorization if disagreeing with Part I conclusion
Member State shall refuse authorization if Part II aspects not complied with
Member State shall refuse authorization if ethics committee issues negative opinion
Member State must provide appeal procedure for authorization refusal
Negative Part I conclusion deemed conclusion of all Member States
Part I conclusion deemed decision if Member State fails to notify sponsor in time
Package investigational products to prevent contamination and deterioration during transport and storage
Member States shall not request additional Part I information after the reporting date
The notification date is when the authorization decision is notified to the sponsor
Authorization expires if no subjects enrolled within 2 years of notification date
Authorization extension must be approved following Chapter III procedure
Application assessors must not have conflicts of interest with the trial
Application assessors must be independent of the sponsor and trial site
Application assessors must be free of undue influence
Persons assessing the application must have no financial interests affecting impartiality
Persons assessing the application must have no personal interests affecting impartiality
Persons assessing the application shall make an annual declaration of financial interests
Assessment must be done jointly by persons with necessary qualifications and experience
At least one layperson shall participate in the assessment
Applications for trials with minors require assessment based on pediatric expertise
Applications for trials with incapacitated subjects require assessment based on relevant expertise
Maintain sufficient quantities of investigational products to reconfirm specifications if needed
Assess clinical trial applications based on expertise in the relevant condition and population
Give specific consideration to applications involving specific groups or subgroups of subjects
Give specific consideration to circumstances of clinical trial conduct for Article 35 applications
Allow sponsors to request assessment limited to Part I aspects
Allow sponsors to apply for Part II assessment within 2 years of Part I conclusion
Sponsors must declare no new substantial scientific information when applying for Part II assessment
Sponsors should promptly notify investigators/institutions of findings that could affect subject safety
Applications limited to Part II aspects must be submitted within 2 years
Sponsors may withdraw applications at any time until the reporting date
Application withdrawals must be for all Member States concerned
Reasons for withdrawal shall be communicated through the EU portal
Sponsors may resubmit applications after refusal or withdrawal
Resubmitted applications shall be treated as new applications
Sponsors may extend authorized trials to additional Member States
Sponsors should determine appropriate extent and nature of monitoring
Sponsors shall submit application dossier to additional Member State through EU portal
Application dossier may only be submitted after notification of initial authorization decision
Reporting Member State for additional application shall be same as for initial authorization
Additional Member State shall notify sponsor of decision within 52 days of application submission
Additional Member State shall issue single decision on trial authorization status
Conditional authorization is restricted to conditions that cannot be fulfilled at time of authorization
Additional Member State may disagree with reporting Member State's conclusion
Verify investigational product is supplied only to eligible subjects at specified doses
Additional Member States may disagree with the reporting Member State on Part I assessment on specified grounds
Member States must communicate disagreement with justification through the EU portal
Additional Member States may communicate relevant considerations within specified timeframe
Only the reporting Member State may request additional information from the sponsor
Communications must be made through the EU portal
Verify investigator is enrolling only eligible subjects
Verify source documents and trial records are accurate, complete and up-to-date
The reporting Member State may extend the review period by up to 31 days
The sponsor must submit additional requested information within 12 days of receipt
Member States shall jointly review any additional information with the original application
The coordinated review of additional information must be completed within 12 days
Further consolidation shall be performed within 7 days of the coordinated review
The reporting Member State shall record how all Member State considerations were addressed
Monitor must inform investigator of CRF entry errors, omissions, or illegibility
Additional information requests and responses must be submitted through the EU portal
Additional Member States shall assess Part II of the assessment report for their territory
Additional Member States may request justified additional information from sponsors
Member States may extend the assessment period by up to 31 days for additional information
Sponsors must submit requested additional information within 12 days of receipt
Member States shall complete assessment within 19 days of receiving additional information
Monitoring reports should summarize findings, deviations, and actions taken
Sponsor should document review and follow-up of monitoring reports
Additional information requests must be submitted through the EU portal
Additional Member States must include Part II conclusions in decisions if Part I is acceptable
Additional Member States must refuse authorization if disagreeing with Part I conclusions
Additional Member States must refuse authorization if Part II requirements are not met
Additional Member States must refuse authorization if ethics committee issues negative opinion
Additional Member States must provide an appeal procedure for authorization refusals
Regulatory authorities should not routinely request audit reports
Sponsors must not submit an application dossier if a Chapter III procedure is pending for that trial
A substantial modification may only be implemented if approved per the Chapter III procedure
Adding a clinical trial site requires approval as a substantial modification
Changing a principal investigator requires approval as a substantial modification
Sponsors must submit substantial modification applications via the EU portal
Substantial modification applications must be submitted to concerned Member States
Sponsor must ensure clinical trial reports are prepared and provided to regulatory agencies as required
The reporting Member State for a substantial modification shall be the same as for the initial authorization
Member States may communicate considerations on validation within 5 days of application submission
The reporting Member State shall validate the application within 6 days of submission
The reporting Member State shall notify the sponsor via EU portal if the modification concerns Part I
The reporting Member State shall notify the sponsor if the application dossier is complete
If no notification is given in 6 days, the modification is deemed to concern Part I
If no notification is given in 6 days, the application dossier is deemed complete
Inform sponsor through EU portal if application dossier is incomplete
Set maximum 10 days for sponsor to comment or complete application
Notify sponsor within 5 days if application complies with requirements
Deem application lapsed if sponsor doesn't respond within given period
Use date of sponsor notification as validation date of application
Use last day of notification period as validation date if sponsor not notified
Names and addresses of laboratories and institutions involved must be listed
The reporting Member State shall assess the application regarding Part I aspects
The assessment report shall contain a conclusion on Part I aspects
The reporting Member State shall submit the final assessment report via the EU portal
The final assessment report shall be submitted within 38 days from the validation date
The final report shall be submitted to the sponsor and other concerned Member States
The assessment shall determine if the trial remains low-intervention after modification
Specify primary and secondary endpoints to be measured
The initial assessment phase must be performed by the reporting Member State within 19 days from validation date
The coordinated review phase must be performed within 12 days from the end of the initial assessment phase
The consolidation phase must be performed by the reporting Member State within 7 days from end of coordinated review
The reporting Member State shall develop a draft assessment report during the initial assessment phase
All Member States concerned shall jointly review the application during the coordinated review phase
The reporting Member State shall finalize the assessment report during the consolidation phase
The final assessment report shall be submitted to the sponsor and all other Member States concerned
Establish procedures for breaking randomization codes
The reporting Member State may request additional information from the sponsor
The reporting Member State may extend the review period by up to 31 days
The sponsor shall submit requested additional information within the period set by the reporting Member State
The period for sponsors to submit additional information shall not exceed 12 days
Member States shall jointly review any additional information provided by the sponsor
The coordinated review of additional information shall be performed within 12 days of receipt
Further consolidation shall be performed within 7 days from the end of the coordinated review
Specify type and duration of subject follow-up after adverse events
The reporting Member State shall take due account of other Member States' considerations
The reporting Member State shall record how all considerations have been dealt with
The sponsor must provide additional information within the determined period
Additional information requests and responses shall be submitted through the EU portal
Member States shall notify the sponsor of the decision through the EU portal
Notification shall be done by way of a single decision within five days from the reporting date
Authorisation subject to conditions is restricted to conditions that cannot be fulfilled at authorisation time
Member States may disagree with the reporting Member State's conclusion only on specified grounds
Member States must communicate disagreement with justification through the EU portal
Member States shall refuse to authorize modifications if disagreeing with reporting Member State's conclusion
Member States shall refuse authorization if ethics committee issues negative opinion valid for entire Member State
Member States shall provide an appeal procedure for authorization refusals
The IB contents must be approved by the disciplines that generated the data
An extensive IB may not be necessary for marketed products with widely understood pharmacology
The reporting Member State's conclusion on Part I modifications is deemed to be the conclusion of all Member States
Member States must notify sponsors of decisions on substantial modifications within the specified period
If no decision is notified in time, the assessment report conclusion is deemed to be the Member State's decision
Member States must notify sponsors within 6 days if a modification concerns Part II of the assessment report
Member States must notify sponsors within 6 days if the application dossier is complete
If no notification is made in 6 days, the modification is deemed to concern Part II and the dossier deemed complete
For investigator-sponsored trials, the sponsor-investigator should determine if a brochure is available from the manufacturer
Member State must inform sponsor if modification doesn't concern Part II or application is incomplete
Member State must set maximum 10 days for sponsor to comment or complete application
Member State must notify sponsor within 5 days if application complies with requirements
Modification deemed to concern Part II if Member State doesn't notify sponsor in time
Application dossier deemed complete if Member State doesn't notify sponsor in time
Application lapses if sponsor doesn't comment or complete application in given time
IB must contain a table of contents
IB must include a brief summary (preferably not exceeding two pages)
The validation date shall be the last day of the period if sponsor is not notified
Member State shall assess the application and submit Part II of assessment report to sponsor
Member State shall notify decision on substantial modification within 38 days of validation date
Member State may request additional information from sponsor with justification
Member State may extend review period by maximum 31 days to obtain additional information
Sponsor shall submit requested additional information within period set by Member State
Member State shall not set information submission period exceeding 12 days from request
Include instructions for storage and handling of dosage forms
Member State shall complete assessment within 19 days of receiving additional information
Application lapses if sponsor doesn't provide additional information within set period
Additional information requests and responses must be submitted through the EU portal
Member State shall refuse authorization if Part II aspects are not complied with
Member State shall refuse authorization if ethics committee issues negative opinion
Member State must provide an appeal procedure for authorization refusal
Substantial modification deemed authorized if Member State doesn't notify sponsor within set period
Substantial modifications must be validated in accordance with Article 17
Part I aspects shall be assessed according to Article 18
Part II aspects shall be assessed according to Article 22
Member States must assess substantial modifications for their territory within 38 days
Member States may request additional information from sponsors with justification
Member States may extend assessment period by up to 31 days to review additional information
Discuss findings on absorption and bioavailability of the investigational product and metabolites
Describe toxicological effects found in relevant animal studies under appropriate headings
Sponsors shall submit requested additional information within the period set by the Member State
The period for submitting additional information shall not exceed 12 days from receipt of the request
Member States shall complete assessment within 19 days of receiving additional information
Applications shall be deemed lapsed if sponsors do not provide requested information in time
Additional information requests and submissions shall be made through the EU portal
Member States shall notify sponsors of substantial modification decisions via the EU portal
Notification of substantial modification decisions shall be done within 5 days of specified dates
The reporting Member State's conclusion on Part I modifications shall be deemed the conclusion of all Member States
Member States may disagree with the reporting Member State's conclusion only on specific grounds
Member States may disagree if participation would lead to inferior treatment compared to normal practice
Member States may disagree if there is infringement of national law as referred to in Article 90
Member States may disagree based on subject safety and data reliability considerations
Disagreeing Member States must communicate disagreement with justification via the EU portal
Identify countries where the investigational product has been marketed or approved
Summarize significant information from marketed use of the product
Member State must include conclusion on Part II aspects in decision on substantial modification
Member State shall refuse authorization if disagreeing with reporting Member State on Part I aspects
Member State shall refuse authorization if Part II aspects are not complied with
Member State shall refuse authorization if ethics committee issues negative opinion valid for entire state
Member State must provide appeal procedure for authorization refusal
Reporting Member State's conclusion of unacceptable Part I modification applies to all Member States
Member State must notify sponsor of decision within specified time periods
The application dossier must contain all documentation for validation and assessment
The application must include information on the conduct of the clinical trial
The application must include information on the sponsor, investigators, subjects, and trial sites
The application must include information on investigational and auxiliary medicinal products
The application must include measures to protect subjects
Low-intervention trial claims must be justified in the application
The application for substantial modifications must contain all required documentation
Include subsections on Pharmacology, Pharmacokinetics, and Toxicology in Nonclinical Studies
Include the EU trial number when referencing modified clinical trials
Provide a clear description of the substantial modification
Explain the reasons for the substantial modification
Present supporting data for the substantial modification when necessary
Describe the consequences of the modification on subject rights and safety
Describe the consequences of the modification on data reliability and robustness
Clinical trials conducted outside the EU must follow principles equivalent to this Regulation
Clinical trials started after the Article 99 date must be registered in WHO ICTRP before starting
Trials started before Article 99 date must be registered in WHO ICTRP or published in peer-reviewed journal
Data not complying with paragraphs 3-6 shall not be considered in trial authorization applications
Member State shall determine language requirements for the application dossier
Monitor must review investigator/institution and sponsor files before trial close-out
All documents should be available for regulatory authority inspection
Member States shall consider accepting a commonly understood medical language for documentation not addressed to subjects
The Commission may adopt delegated acts to amend Annexes I and II to adapt to technical progress
The anticipated benefits must justify the foreseeable risks and inconveniences
Compliance with the risk-benefit justification must be constantly monitored
Subjects or their representatives must be informed according to Article 29(2) to (6)
Subjects or their representatives must give informed consent according to Article 29(1), (7) and (8)
The rights of subjects to physical and mental integrity must be protected
Clinical trials must be designed to minimize pain, discomfort, fear and risk for subjects
Risk threshold and degree of distress must be defined in the protocol
Subject risk and distress must be constantly monitored
Medical care for subjects must be provided by a qualified doctor or dentist
Subjects must be provided contact details for an entity to receive further information
No undue influence, including financial, may be exerted on subjects to participate
Sponsors may request consent to use subject data outside the trial protocol for scientific purposes
Scientific research using trial data must comply with applicable data protection laws
Subjects may withdraw from a trial at any time by revoking informed consent
Withdrawal of consent shall not affect use of data obtained before withdrawal
Informed consent must be written, dated and signed by the interviewer and subject
Alternative consent methods may be used if subject cannot write
An impartial witness must be present for alternative consent methods
Subjects must receive a copy of the informed consent document
Informed consent shall be documented
Adequate time shall be given for subjects to consider participation
Information must enable understanding of trial nature, objectives, benefits, risks
Information must explain subject rights including right to refuse or withdraw
Information must explain trial conditions and expected duration of participation
Information must explain possible treatment alternatives and follow-up measures
Information must be comprehensive, concise, clear, relevant and understandable
Information must be provided in a prior interview with a qualified investigating team member
Information must include details about the applicable damage compensation system
Information must include the EU trial number
Information must include details on availability of clinical trial results
Information shall be prepared in writing
Special attention shall be paid to information needs of specific populations and individuals
It shall be verified that the subject has understood the information
Both incapacitated person and legal representative may need to sign informed consent form
Minors capable of forming an opinion may need to assent in addition to legal representative consent
Member States may allow simplified informed consent for certain cluster trials
Simplified informed consent must meet conditions set out in Article 30 paragraph 3
Simplified informed consent must include information from Article 29(2) points a, b, d and e
Document site visits and findings by the monitor in monitoring visit reports
Document agreements and discussions on trial administration in relevant communications
Obtain signed informed consent forms from each subject prior to trial participation
Subjects must be informed they can refuse to participate or withdraw at any time without detriment
The potential subject must not object to participating after being informed
Simplified informed consent must not contradict national law in the Member State
Simplified consent may be used if groups rather than individuals are allocated to receive different investigational products
Simplified consent may be used for low-intervention trials using products per marketing authorization terms
The protocol must justify reasons for simplified consent and describe information provided to subjects
Maintain a subject screening log to document identification of pre-trial screening subjects
Investigators shall document all refusals and withdrawals from the clinical trial
No data shall be collected from subjects who refuse to participate or withdraw
Informed consent of legally designated representative must be obtained for incapacitated subjects
Incapacitated subjects must receive trial information in a way adequate to their understanding
Respect incapacitated subjects' explicit wish to refuse or withdraw from the trial
No incentives or financial inducements shall be given to incapacitated subjects or representatives
Clinical trials on incapacitated persons must relate directly to their medical condition
Participation must be expected to produce direct benefit outweighing risks for incapacitated subjects
Trials on incapacitated subjects may produce benefit for the represented population if minimal risk
National rules prohibiting trials without direct benefit take precedence
Incapacitated subjects shall participate in informed consent as much as possible
Clinical trials on minors must meet all conditions in Article 28
Investigator must submit final report to IRB/IEC and regulatory authorities if required
Prepare clinical study report documenting trial results and interpretation
Subjects should be properly informed on the processing of their personal data
A correct-mark symbol indicates an element should be included for an age group
A circle symbol indicates an element is optional for an age group
Monitoring should contribute to subject safety in clinical trials
Analyze reasons for child's objections to trial participation
Unauthorised auxiliary medicinal products may be used in justified cases
Describe how the investigational product will be administered
Address pain, discomfort, and fear associated with trial procedures
Allow participants to withdraw consent for future use of biological samples
Comply with General Data Protection Regulation (679/2016) for biological samples
The Agency should set up and maintain an EU database for clinical trial information
A summary of results should be presented in terms understandable to participants
Clinical trials should be subject to prior authorisation
Effects of medicinal products should be studied in people with multiple chronic conditions
Subjects should have opportunity to ask questions at any time
Adequate time should be provided for subject to consider decision
The EU clinical trial database should be publicly accessible
Informed consent is a subject's free and voluntary expression of willingness to participate
Clinical trials shall undergo scientific and ethical review before authorization
Submit final Part I of assessment report through the EU portal
Additional information requests and responses shall be submitted through the EU portal
Base non-clinical information on studies complying with good laboratory practice
Subjects may withdraw consent for data use outside the protocol at any time
Subjects must be informed about availability of trial results summary in the EU database
Clinical trials on incapacitated subjects must be essential and data cannot be obtained otherwise
Obtain informed consent from the legally designated representative of minors
Provide age-appropriate information to minors by trained investigators
Respect the explicit wish of a capable minor to refuse or withdraw participation
Do not provide incentives except compensation for expenses and lost earnings
Clinical trials must investigate treatments for conditions only occurring in minors
Clinical trials must relate to a condition the minor suffers from
Clinical trials with minors must have scientific grounds for expected direct benefit outweighing risks
Clinical trials with minors must pose only minimal risk if no direct benefit is expected
Minors shall participate in informed consent process adapted to their age and maturity
Express informed consent must be obtained if minor reaches legal competence during trial
Trials with pregnant/breastfeeding women must have potential direct benefit outweighing risks
Trials with no direct benefit for pregnant/breastfeeding women must meet additional conditions
Clinical trials on pregnant women must have comparable effectiveness to non-pregnant women
Clinical trials on pregnant women must benefit pregnant/breastfeeding women or embryos/fetuses/children
Clinical trials on pregnant women must pose minimal risk to woman, embryo, fetus or child
Research on breastfeeding women must avoid adverse impacts on child health
No incentives or financial inducements allowed for clinical trial subjects except expense compensation
Member States may maintain additional measures for certain groups in clinical trials
Informed consent may be obtained after including the subject in urgent clinical trials
Information on the trial may be given after including the subject in urgent clinical trials
The decision to include a subject must be taken at the time of first intervention
The subject must be unable to provide prior consent due to a sudden serious medical condition
There must be scientific grounds to expect a direct clinically relevant benefit for the subject
It must not be possible to obtain prior consent from the subject's legal representative
The investigator must certify no prior objections from the subject to participate
Clinical trials in emergency situations must relate directly to the subject's medical condition
Emergency clinical trials must pose minimal risk to subjects compared to standard treatment
Informed consent must be sought after emergency intervention to continue trial participation
For incapacitated subjects, informed consent shall be sought from legal representative without delay
Trial information must be given to incapacitated subjects and representatives as soon as possible
For other subjects, informed consent shall be sought from subject or representative without delay
Inform the subject or legally designated representative as soon as possible about Article 29(2)
Obtain informed consent from the subject as soon as they are capable, if consent was from representative
Inform subjects of their right to object to use of trial data if consent is not given
Notify Member States of clinical trial start through EU portal within 15 days
Notify Member States of first subject visit through EU portal within 15 days
Notify Member States of end of subject recruitment within 15 days via EU portal
Notify Member States of clinical trial end within 15 days via EU portal
Notify all Member States of trial end in all states within 15 days via EU portal
Notify Member States of trial end in all states and third countries within 15 days
Apply paragraph 1 rules in case of recruitment restart
Sponsors shall submit a summary of clinical trial results to the EU database within one year of trial end
The clinical trial results summary shall include content as specified in Annex IV
A layperson summary of trial results must accompany the main summary
The layperson summary content shall be as specified in Annex V
The protocol must specify when results will be submitted if not possible within one year
Marketing authorization applicants shall submit the clinical study report to the EU database within 30 days
The Commission shall produce guidelines for formatting and sharing of voluntarily shared raw data
Sponsor must notify Member States of temporary trial halt via EU portal within 15 days
Sponsor must include reasons for temporary trial halt in notification
Sponsor must notify Member States of trial restart via EU portal within 15 days
Trial end date is 2 years after temporary halt if not restarted
Early termination date is deemed the trial end date
Sponsor must notify Member States of early termination reasons via EU portal
Sponsor should provide follow-up measures for subjects after early termination when appropriate
Submit summary of intermediate data analysis results to EU database within one year of analysis date
Notify Member States of temporary halt or early termination through EU portal
Submit notification of temporary halt or early termination within 15 days
Include reasons and follow-up measures for temporary halt or early termination
Restart after temporary halt requires authorization as substantial modification
Commission may adopt delegated acts to amend Annexes IV and V
The European Medicines Agency shall set up an electronic database for safety reporting
The Agency shall maintain the electronic database for safety reporting
The safety reporting database shall be a module of the Eudravigilance database
The Agency shall develop a web-based form for reporting suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions
Investigators shall record and document adverse events identified as critical in the protocol
Investigators shall report critical adverse events to the sponsor as specified in the protocol
Investigators shall record and document all adverse events, unless specified otherwise in the protocol
Investigators shall report all serious adverse events to the sponsor
Serious adverse events must be reported within 24 hours of knowledge
Investigators shall send follow-up reports on serious adverse events to sponsors
Sponsors shall keep detailed records of all reported adverse events
Post-trial serious adverse events shall be reported to the sponsor without delay
Sponsors must report unexpected serious adverse reactions electronically to the Agency
Report all suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions to investigational medicinal products in the trial
Report adverse reactions occurring at trial sites in the EU or third countries
Report adverse reactions related to the same active substance in trials in third countries
Report adverse reactions from trials sponsored by the same parent company
Report adverse reactions from jointly developed products with formal agreements
Report adverse reactions identified after the end of the clinical trial
Report fatal or life-threatening SUSARs within 7 days of sponsor awareness
Report non-fatal/non-life-threatening SUSARs within 15 days of sponsor awareness
Report SUSARs that become fatal/life-threatening within 7 days of new status awareness
Submit initial incomplete SUSAR reports when necessary for timely reporting
Follow up incomplete SUSAR reports with complete reports
Sponsors without database access may report to Member State with agreement
Member States shall report suspected unexpected serious adverse reactions
Sponsors must submit annual safety reports to the Agency for each investigational medicinal product
Annual safety reports shall be submitted through the database referred to in Article 40(1)
Sponsors may submit a single safety report for multiple investigational products if specified in the protocol
Annual safety reports must only contain aggregate and anonymised data
The Agency shall forward reported information electronically to concerned Member States
Member States shall cooperate in assessing information reported under Articles 42 and 43
The Commission may set up rules on cooperation between Member States via implementing acts
The responsible ethics committee shall be involved in assessing information if required by Member State law
Technical aspects for safety reporting are contained in Annex III
The Commission may amend Annex III to improve subject protection via delegated acts
Safety reporting for auxiliary medicinal products shall follow Directive 2001/83/EC
The sponsor shall ensure the clinical trial is conducted according to the protocol
The investigator shall ensure the clinical trial is conducted according to the protocol
The sponsor shall ensure the clinical trial follows good clinical practice principles
The investigator shall ensure the clinical trial follows good clinical practice principles
The sponsor shall take into account ICH guidelines on good clinical practice
The Commission shall make ICH guidelines on good clinical practice publicly available
The sponsor shall adequately monitor the conduct of a clinical trial
The sponsor shall determine monitoring extent based on trial characteristics
The investigator shall be a medical doctor as defined in national law
Investigators must have necessary scientific knowledge and experience in patient care
Other trial staff shall be qualified by education, training and experience
Clinical trial facilities must be suitable for conducting the trial
Investigational medicinal products shall be traceable
Investigational products must be stored, returned and/or destroyed appropriately
Sponsors must notify Member States of serious breaches via the EU portal
Serious breach notifications must be sent within 7 days of awareness
Sponsors must notify Member States of unexpected events affecting benefit-risk balance
Unexpected event notifications must be sent within 15 days of awareness
Application dossier must contain information on traceability of medicinal products
Application dossier must contain information on storage of medicinal products
Sponsors shall submit inspection reports from third country authorities to Member States via EU portal
Sponsors shall provide translations of inspection reports when requested by a Member State
Sponsors and investigators shall take urgent safety measures if an event affects benefit-risk balance
Sponsors shall notify Member States of urgent safety measures via EU portal within 7 days
Sponsors shall provide investigators with the investigator's brochure
Sponsors shall update the investigator's brochure when new safety information is available
Sponsors shall review the investigator's brochure at least annually
Information must be reported, interpreted and verified accurately
Confidentiality of records and personal data must be protected
Implement technical and organizational measures to protect information and personal data
Protect data against unauthorized access, disclosure, alteration, destruction and loss
Sponsor and investigator must keep a clinical trial master file
Clinical trial master file must contain essential documents for trial verification
Clinical trial master file must be readily available and accessible to Member States
Sponsors and investigators shall archive clinical trial master file content for at least 25 years after trial end
Clinical trial master file content must be readily available and accessible to competent authorities upon request
Any transfer of ownership of clinical trial master file content shall be documented
Sponsors shall appoint individuals responsible for archives
Access to archives shall be restricted to appointed individuals
Archived clinical trial master file content must remain complete and legible for the required retention period
Any alteration to clinical trial master file content shall be traceable
Only authorized auxiliary medicinal products may be used in clinical trials
Include justification in protocol for using unauthorized auxiliary medicinal products
Allow entry of unauthorized auxiliary medicinal products for clinical trials
Obtain authorization for manufacturing and importing investigational medicinal products
Have suitable premises, equipment and control facilities for manufacturing/importing
Have continuous services of at least one qualified person meeting specified conditions
Applicant shall specify types and forms of investigational medicinal product manufactured or imported
Applicant shall specify manufacturing or import operations in the application
Applicant shall specify manufacturing process where relevant in the application
Applicant shall specify site where investigational medicinal products are manufactured
Applicant shall specify site in the Union to which products are imported
Applicant shall provide detailed information concerning the qualified person
Articles 42 to 45 and point (e) of Article 46 of Directive 2001/83/EC apply to the authorisation
Investigational medicinal products must be used exclusively in hospitals, health centres or clinics in the same clinical trial
Preparation of investigational medicinal products must be carried out in legally authorized facilities
Member States shall subject preparation processes to appropriate and proportionate requirements
Preparation processes shall be subject to regular inspections
The qualified person shall ensure each batch of investigational medicinal products complies with Article 63 requirements
The qualified person shall certify that Article 63 requirements are fulfilled for each batch
The sponsor shall make batch certifications available upon request of the Member State concerned
Investigational medicinal products shall be manufactured by applying good manufacturing practice
Good manufacturing practice must ensure the quality of investigational medicinal products
The Commission shall adopt delegated acts to specify principles of good manufacturing practice
The Commission shall publish detailed guidelines on good manufacturing practice
Imported investigational medicinal products must meet equivalent quality standards
Member States shall ensure compliance through inspections
Articles 61, 62 and 63 apply to authorized investigational medicinal products only for modifications not covered by marketing authorization
Unauthorized auxiliary medicinal products must be manufactured according to good manufacturing practice in Article 63(1)
Authorized auxiliary medicinal products with modifications not covered by marketing authorization must meet Article 63(1) standards
Outer and immediate packaging of unauthorized investigational and auxiliary medicinal products must identify trial contact persons
Outer and immediate packaging must include information to identify the clinical trial
Outer and immediate packaging must include information to identify the medicinal product
Outer and immediate packaging must include information related to the use of the medicinal product
Information on outer and immediate packaging shall ensure subject safety
Information on outer packaging and immediate packaging shall be clearly legible
Outer and immediate packaging must include information listed in Annex VI
Authorized investigational and auxiliary medicinal products shall be labeled per Article 66(1)
Authorized products may be labeled according to Title V of Directive 2001/83/EC
Additional trial and contact details must appear on packaging when required for safety or data integrity
Additional packaging details for authorized investigational products are listed in Annex VI section C
Radiopharmaceuticals used as diagnostic investigational or auxiliary medicinal products must be labeled appropriately
Labeling of radiopharmaceuticals must ensure subject safety
Labeling of radiopharmaceuticals must ensure reliability and robustness of clinical trial data
The language of label information shall be determined by the concerned Member State
Medicinal products may be labeled in multiple languages
A clinical trial may have one or multiple sponsors
Sponsors may delegate tasks via written contract to individuals, companies, institutions or organizations
The investigator and sponsor may be the same person
Clinical trials with multiple sponsors must have a written contract specifying responsibilities
Co-sponsors shall jointly designate a sponsor responsible for authorization procedures
Co-sponsors shall jointly designate a sponsor as contact point for questions
Co-sponsors shall jointly designate a sponsor responsible for implementing measures
Principal investigator shall ensure trial site compliance with regulations
Principal investigator shall assign tasks to team members appropriately
Sponsors not established in the EU must ensure a legal representative is established in the EU
The legal representative shall be responsible for ensuring sponsor's compliance with the Regulation
The legal representative shall be the addressee for all communications with the sponsor
Member States may waive legal representative requirement for trials conducted solely in their territory
Sponsors must establish a contact person in Member State if legal representative requirement is waived
For multi-state trials, Member States may waive legal representative if sponsor has EU contact person
Member States shall ensure systems for compensation for damage to trial subjects are in place
Compensation systems must be in the form of insurance, guarantee, or similar arrangement
Compensation systems must be appropriate to the nature and extent of risk
Sponsors and investigators shall use the compensation system of the Member State where trial is conducted
Additional compensation not required for low-intervention trials if existing system covers possible damage
Member States shall not require additional compensation for low-intervention trials in certain cases
Member States may revoke the authorization of a clinical trial
Member States may suspend a clinical trial
Member States may require sponsors to modify any aspect of a clinical trial
Member States must ask sponsors/investigators for opinion before taking corrective measures
Sponsors/investigators must deliver their opinion within seven days
Member States shall inform all concerned Member States after taking a corrective measure
Member States shall appoint inspectors to supervise compliance with this Regulation
Member States shall ensure inspectors are adequately qualified and trained
Member States must notify others of planned inspections via the EU portal
Member States shall inform others of inspection findings after completion
Inspection fees may be waived for non-commercial sponsors
The Agency shall coordinate inspections between Member States
Member States must draw up an inspection report after conducting an inspection
Inspection reports shall be made available to the inspected entity and sponsor
Inspection reports must be submitted through the EU portal
The Commission may conduct controls to verify Member States' supervision of compliance
The Commission may verify compliance with Directive 2001/83/EC for trials outside the EU
The Commission may verify compliance with Article 25(5) for trials outside the EU
Union controls must be organized in cooperation with concerned Member States
The Commission shall prepare a program for Union controls with Member States
The Commission shall report on findings of each Union control
Control reports shall be submitted through the EU portal
The Agency shall set up and maintain an EU portal for clinical trial data submission
The EU portal shall be technically advanced
The EU portal shall be user-friendly
The EU portal shall avoid unnecessary work
Data submitted through the EU portal shall be stored in the EU database
The Agency shall set up and maintain the EU database
The Agency shall be the controller of the EU database
The EU database shall identify each clinical trial by a unique EU trial number
Sponsors shall refer to the EU trial number in subsequent submissions
All data in the EU database shall be in an easily searchable format
Related data shall be grouped together by EU trial number
Hyperlinks shall link related data and documents across Agency databases
EU database shall support recording data on unapproved medicinal products
EU medicinal product number shall be issued for every unapproved product
EU active substances code shall be issued for each new active substance
Product/substance numbers shall be mentioned in all subsequent applications
Data describing medicinal products and substances must comply with Union and international standards
Relevant product and active substance numbers must be referenced for products with existing marketing authorization
The EU database shall be publicly accessible
Confidentiality may be justified to protect personal data in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 45/2001
Confidentiality may be justified to protect commercially confidential information
Confidentiality may be justified to protect communication between Member States on assessment reports
Confidentiality may be justified to ensure effective supervision of clinical trials by Member States
Application dossier shall not be publicly accessible before decision on clinical trial
EU database shall contain personal data only as necessary for stated purposes
No personal data of subjects shall be publicly accessible
User interface of EU database shall be available in all official EU languages
Sponsor shall update EU database with non-substantial trial changes relevant for supervision
Agency, Commission and Member States shall ensure data subjects can exercise data rights
Inaccurate and unlawfully processed data shall be deleted
Corrections and deletions shall be carried out within 60 days of a data subject request
The Agency shall draw up functional specifications for the EU portal and database
The Agency shall create a timeframe for implementing the EU portal and database
The Management Board shall inform the Commission when the systems are fully functional
The Commission shall publish a notice when conditions are fulfilled
Each Member State shall designate one national contact point
Each Member State shall communicate their national contact point to the Commission
The Agency shall maintain and update the EU portal and EU database
The Commission shall support Member State cooperation referred to in Article 44(2)
A Clinical Trials Coordination and Advisory Group (CTAG) shall be established
The CTAG shall support information exchange between Member States and Commission
The CTAG shall assist the Commission in providing support referred to in Article 84
The CTAG shall prepare recommendations on criteria for selecting a reporting Member State
